On May 28, five MAPS (Moody Advanced Professional Studies) teams competed in the first Scots Tank for a grand cash prize sponsored by Credit Union of Texas.

Modeled after Shark Tank, the entrepreneurship reality show, student presentations were judged by a panel of business and community leaders including Charlotte Jones Anderson of the Dallas Cowboys, Matt Hickey of AT&T, Ollie Chandhok of the Dallas Business Journal, Robert Campbell of Credit Union of Texas and as moderator, Trey Bowles of the Dallas Entrepreneurship Center.

The businesses pitched included college guidance services, a talent-booking website, portable water filters, mobile salon and a crowdsourcing tutoring program. This year's winner was team Campus Captured with Nell Covington, Ashlee Newton, Trip Lee and Caroline Dugan.

Looking for a way to honor the band seniors while honoring social distancing guidelines, Band Director Reagan Brumley and the rest of the band staff began planning a virtual celebration, led by the seniors themselves.

The virtual banquet, held May 14, allowed the band to gather virtually via Zoom to reminisce, laugh, celebrate individual achievements and take one last look back – all while celebrating safely at home with family. Then on a rainy Saturday, Mr. Brumley made the rounds to visit the homes of each graduating senior and hand-deliver every band award.

Way to go Highlander Band, proving to us all, that Scots find a way!

Emergency donations are requested to help purchase school supplies. Please consider donating to the Dallas ISD Tornado Relief Fund established through the Dallas Foundation. Every contribution, no matter how small, will help. https://www.dallasisd.org/tornadorelief

The HPISD Board of Trustees is seeking nominations for the name of the district's newest elementary school located at 8385 Durham. The school is scheduled to open as its own entity in August 2020. The building is currently serving as the educational home for Hyer Elementary after initially opening to house University Park Elementary during the 2017-18 school year.

The name to be considered should be either:

-an individual who has made a significant contribution to society and/or education whose name will lend prestige and status to the school, and who has served HPISD or the local community, or;
-a place or geographical location that is significant to the Highland Park ISD community.

Nominations will be accepted from April 15-August 15, 2019. The board is planning to select and announce a name for the new school in September. Follow the link below to access the nomination form: https://www.hpisd.org/apps/form/form.HIGHPAR-S.rnlANtt.1vC
